column1: Rudy,"Rudy joined the Navy in April of 1945 and immediately volunteered for ""secret and hazardous duty"" with the Amphibious Scouts and Raiders

column4: Florida

column8: he completed numerous specialized schools and deployed routinely to the Mediterranean and Caribbean areas with the Naval Amphibious Forces. Rudy became a proficient combat swimmer and expert in small-boat operations. In 1962

column10: becoming one of their most distinguished members.In 1967
column11: Rudy was advanced to the rank of Master Chief Petty Officer and
column12: between combat tours
column13: served as the senior enlisted position of Command Master Chief.  From 1968-1970
column14: Rudy completed two combat deployments to Vietnam.  Among his numerous awards
column15: Rudy earned the Bronze Star Medal for heroic action during more than 45 combat operations.  During and after his stint in Vietnam
column16: Rudy was delegated the ""Chief SEAL
column17: and set physical and operational standards at SEAL Team TWO.In the late 1980's
column18: Rudy became the Naval Special Warfare Community ""Bull Frog
column19: a distinguishing award presented to the SEAL serving the longest time on active duty.  Instead of retiring
column20: Rudy was selected as the Senior Enlisted Advisor to USSOCOM.  In August of 1988
column21: Rudy headed to Tampa
column22: Florida and entered into the ""inner circle"" of the Special Operations Command to advise on all enlisted matters of the Joint command.  For his extraordinary performance
column23: Rudy was awarded the Defense Superior Service Medal - an award not often given to an enlisted man.Master Chief Rudy retired from the U.S. Navy after completing over 45 years continuous activity.  He was honorably discharged on August 1
column24: 1990.  Rudy and Marge

It only can happen in your wildest dreams. So many thousands ofSurvivorsuper-duper fans would do anything to be in my position.How will you play differently than you did in your past season?My basic strategy is the same forSurvivoras it is for life: make friends. Anyone who comes into this game believing
column28: ""I'm not here to make friends"" is playing a losing game. What's different this time is that some of the people I will be playing with already are friends. I need to obfuscate my existing relationships

column34: while also recognizing that all of them are incredibly capable and not to be underestimated.",1,0

column9: Jeff Probst.What doesSurvivormean to you and your family?Everything.Survivorhas been a constant in my life

column11: during
column12: and after my time on the show. It may sound silly to some
column13: butSurvivoris far more than just a television show for us. It has given us hope

column16: I believe that I am
column17: at my core
column18: the same person that I was when I playedSurvivorfor the first time. Same values
column19: ambitions
column20: passions
column21: and energy. The difference is that I have more opportunities to realize those ambitions and to make a greater impact on the world around me.AsSurvivorapproaches Season 40 and celebrates 20 years on television
column22: what does it mean to be a part of the legacy?I grew up watching Sandra
column23: Boston Rob
column24: Ethan
column27: and Richard Hatch. Playing in Season 40 is like growing up watching Steve Young and Jerry Rice on your favorite football team and then getting to play against them in the Super Bowl. It only can happen in your wildest dreams. So many thousands ofSurvivorsuper-duper fans would do anything to be in my position.How will you play differently than you did in your past season?My basic strategy is the same forSurvivoras it is for life: make friends. Anyone who comes into this game believing
column28: ""I'm not here to make friends"" is playing a losing game. What's different this time is that some of the people I will be playing with already are friends. I need to obfuscate my existing relationships
column29: keep an eye out for others doing the same
column30: and work hard to build ""in-game"" trust that goes beyond liking someone outside of the game.This time around
column31: I can't hide how big of a fan I am. I can have fun with that and subtly play into the larger egos
column32: especially since my life is far less serious and scary than it was last time. My sense is I may come into this game generally underestimated
column33: with at least some people believing that my win was fluky and my social game was choppy. I want them to underestimate me and I will play into that
column34: while also recognizing that all of them are incredibly capable and not to be underestimated.",4,0

column27: and Richard Hatch. Playing in Season 40 is like growing up watching Steve Young and Jerry Rice on your favorite football team and then getting to play against them in the Super Bowl. So many thousands ofSurvivorsuper-duper fans would do anything to be in my position.How will you play differently than you did in your past season?My basic strategy is the same forSurvivoras it is for life: make friends. Anyone who comes into this game believing
column28: ""I'm not here to make friends"" is playing a losing game. What's different this time is that some of the people I will be playing with already are friends. I need to obfuscate my existing relationships

column23: Boston Rob
column24: Ethan
column27: and Richard Hatch. Playing in Season 40 is like growing up watching Steve Young and Jerry Rice on your favorite football team and then getting to play against them in the Super Bowl. So many thousands ofSurvivorsuper-duper fans would do anything to be in my position.How will you play differently than you did in your past season?My basic strategy is the same forSurvivoras it is for life: make friends. Anyone who comes into this game believing
column28: ""I'm not here to make friends"" is playing a losing game. What's different this time is that some of the people I will be playing with already are friends. I need to obfuscate my existing relationships

column6: two-time Academic All-American while at the University of Houston and a 1989 NCAA Top Six Award winner.An abusive relationship forced Jones to retire from track and field for seven years. Despite the odds
column7: she resumed training while working part-time as a corporate lawyer. Within three months
column8: she had qualified for the 1996 US Olympic Trials. Unfortunately
column9: her 19 year-old brother was murdered two weeks before she was to compete. His death and her meager five months of training proved too much to overcome (although she did win the high jump portion of the heptathlon and was in sixth place after three events). After competing in three events
column10: she became severely dehydrated and was forced to withdraw.Such accomplishments have earned Jones a spot in the Cougar Hall of Fame at the University of Houston Athletic/Alumni Center. She was inducted into the GTE (Verizon) Academic All-America Hall of Fame in 1999. She was inducted into the Texas Black Hall of Fame in 2003.Jones largely credits her success to her tumultuous childhood. When she was 13 months old
column11: her father committed suicide while she was in the room. Her mother had four more children
column12: and Jones became their primary caretaker while their mother worked. There were times when the family went without water
column13: electricity or heat. When Jones was a teenager

column23: Boston Rob
column24: Ethan
column27: and Richard Hatch. Playing in Season 40 is like growing up watching Steve Young and Jerry Rice on your favorite football team and then getting to play against them in the Super Bowl. It only can happen in your wildest dreams. So many thousands ofSurvivorsuper-duper fans would do anything to be in my position.How will you play differently than you did in your past season?My basic strategy is the same forSurvivoras it is for life: make friends. Anyone who comes into this game believing
column28: ""I'm not here to make friends"" is playing a losing game. What's different this time is that some of the people I will be playing with already are friends. I need to obfuscate my existing relationships
column29: keep an eye out for others doing the same
column30: and work hard to build ""in-game"" trust that goes beyond liking someone outside of the game.This time around
column31: I can't hide how big of a fan I am. I can have fun with that and subtly play into the larger egos
column32: especially since my life is far less serious and scary than it was last time. My sense is I may come into this game generally underestimated
column33: with at least some people believing that my win was fluky and my social game was choppy. I want them to underestimate me and I will play into that
column34: while also recognizing that all of them are incredibly capable and not to be underestimated.",10,0

column23: Boston Rob
column24: Ethan
column27: and Richard Hatch. Playing in Season 40 is like growing up watching Steve Young and Jerry Rice on your favorite football team and then getting to play against them in the Super Bowl. It only can happen in your wildest dreams. So many thousands ofSurvivorsuper-duper fans would do anything to be in my position.How will you play differently than you did in your past season?My basic strategy is the same forSurvivoras it is for life: make friends. Anyone who comes into this game believing
column28: ""I'm not here to make friends"" is playing a losing game. What's different this time is that some of the people I will be playing with already are friends. I need to obfuscate my existing relationships
column29: keep an eye out for others doing the same
column30: and work hard to build ""in-game"" trust that goes beyond liking someone outside of the game.This time around
column31: I can't hide how big of a fan I am. I can have fun with that and subtly play into the larger egos
column32: especially since my life is far less serious and scary than it was last time. My sense is I may come into this game generally underestimated
column33: with at least some people believing that my win was fluky and my social game was choppy. I want them to underestimate me and I will play into that
column34: while also recognizing that all of them are incredibly capable and not to be underestimated.",11,0

column27: and Richard Hatch. Playing in Season 40 is like growing up watching Steve Young and Jerry Rice on your favorite football team and then getting to play against them in the Super Bowl. It only can happen in your wildest dreams. So many thousands ofSurvivorsuper-duper fans would do anything to be in my position.How will you play differently than you did in your past season?My basic strategy is the same forSurvivoras it is for life: make friends. Anyone who comes into this game believing
column28: ""I'm not here to make friends"" is playing a losing game. What's different this time is that some of the people I will be playing with already are friends. I need to obfuscate my existing relationships
column29: keep an eye out for others doing the same
column30: and work hard to build ""in-game"" trust that goes beyond liking someone outside of the game.This time around
column31: I can't hide how big of a fan I am. I can have fun with that and subtly play into the larger egos
column32: especially since my life is far less serious and scary than it was last time. My sense is I may come into this game generally underestimated
column33: with at least some people believing that my win was fluky and my social game was choppy. I want them to underestimate me and I will play into that
column34: while also recognizing that all of them are incredibly capable and not to be underestimated.",12,0

Anyone who comes into this game believing
column28: ""I'm not here to make friends"" is playing a losing game. What's different this time is that some of the people I will be playing with already are friends. I need to obfuscate my existing relationships
column29: keep an eye out for others doing the same
column30: and work hard to build ""in-game"" trust that goes beyond liking someone outside of the game.This time around
column31: I can't hide how big of a fan I am. I can have fun with that and subtly play into the larger egos
column32: especially since my life is far less serious and scary than it was last time. My sense is I may come into this game generally underestimated
column33: with at least some people believing that my win was fluky and my social game was choppy. I want them to underestimate me and I will play into that
column34: while also recognizing that all of them are incredibly capable and not to be underestimated.",13,0

column27: and Richard Hatch. Playing in Season 40 is like growing up watching Steve Young and Jerry Rice on your favorite football team and then getting to play against them in the Super Bowl. It only can happen in your wildest dreams. So many thousands ofSurvivorsuper-duper fans would do anything to be in my position.How will you play differently than you did in your past season?My basic strategy is the same forSurvivoras it is for life: make friends. Anyone who comes into this game believing
column28: ""I'm not here to make friends"" is playing a losing game. What's different this time is that some of the people I will be playing with already are friends. I need to obfuscate my existing relationships

column12: thanks to the critical success

Probst previously served as host of VH1's ""Rock and Roll Jeopardy""; hosted several programs for FX and traveled around the world as a correspondent for ""Access Hollywood."" In 2001

column1: Jeff Probst,"Emmy Award-winning host and executive producer Jeff Probst returns for the 27th installment of the phenomenally successful series
column2: SURVIVOR.Probst is a four-time Emmy Award winner for ""Outstanding Reality Host."" He has traveled the world serving as both host and executive producer for this popular series. Probst also received an Emmy in 2001 when the show won the first-ever ""Outstanding Non-Fiction Program (Special Class).""In the fall of 2012
column3: Probst premiered his daytime talk show “The Jeff Probst Show
column4: ” encouraging viewers to get off the couch and accomplish what they want in their lives. The one-hour daytime talk show covers topics ranging from newsmakers of the day to families and individuals facing challenges.Probst produced and directed the feature film “Kiss Me
column5: ” starring John Corbett

column8: Emily Osment

column14: thanks to the film’s critical success

column16: Probst partnered with Mark Burnett as creator and executive producer for ""Live for the Moment
column17: for CBS
column18: which featured a person with a daunting diagnosis who wants to live the best life possible and fulfill their dreams.Probst was a regular fill-in for Regis Philbin on ""Live with Regis and Kelly."" He was also a regular guest host for Larry King on ""Larry King Live.” Probst hosts the ""Howard Stern Celebrity Fan Roundtable"" for Howard Stern on Sirius/XM radio. He previously served as host of VH1's ""Rock and Roll Jeopardy""; hosted several programs for FX and traveled around the world as a correspondent for ""Access Hollywood."" In 2001
column19: he was voted one of People Magazine's ""Most Beautiful.""In 2007

I've learned to try and turn every negative into a positive and that life will always throw hard things at you
column17: but it's how you handle those obstacles that matter the most. This game is tough. It's challenging mentally
column18: socially and physically and I know that I can overcome anything is thrown at me no matter how bad it hurts and no matter how many times I break down just because I have in my life.Why You Think You Will Be the Sole SURVIVOR:I will never give up. No matter what happens in the game
column19: there are always loopholes and opportunities to change the way things are going. After my diagnosis
column20: I realized that life may not always deal you a good hand
column21: but it's how you play the hand that can change it around.What Does It Mean to You to Play Survivor with Your Loved One?Jon and I get to experience something that only three or four couples ever have. Blood vs. Water seems to be so much harder than playing as an individual because we have to learn how to maneuver through this social and physical game together. Our sole purpose of being on this show is to challenge ourselves
column22: but to also win to start a family by adoption or surrogacy.",29,0

column1: Jeff Probst,"Jeff Probst is a four-time Emmy Award winner for ""Outstanding Reality Host.""  He has traveled the world serving as both host and executive producer for “Survivor.”   Also
column2: he received an Emmy in 2001 when the show won the first-ever ""Outstanding Non-Fiction Program (Special Class).""

column1: Probst hosts the ""Howard Stern Celebrity Fan Roundtable"" for Howard Stern on Sirius/XM radio and previously served as host of VH1's ""Rock and Roll Jeopardy.”  He hosted several programs for FX and traveled around the world as a correspondent for ""Access Hollywood.""  In 2001
column2: he was voted one of People Magazine's ""Most Beautiful.""

column1: Probst is a proud spokesperson for Taylorsgift.org whose mission is to re-gift life through organ donation.

column28: ""I'm not here to make friends"" is playing a losing game. What's different this time is that some of the people I will be playing with already are friends. I need to obfuscate my existing relationships

column1: Jeff Probst,"Jeff Probst is a four-time Emmy Award winner for ""Outstanding Reality Host."" He has traveled the world serving as both host and executive producer for “Survivor.” Also
column2: he received an Emmy in 2001 when the show won the first-ever ""Outstanding Non-Fiction Program (Special Class)."" Probst is a New York Times best-selling author of a kid’s adventure series
column3: STRANDED. Probst is also a feature film director. In 2002
column4: he wrote and directed ""Finder's Fee
column5: starring Ryan Reynolds
column6: James Earl Jones
column7: Robert Forster and Matthew Lillard. Most recently
column8: he produced and directed the feature film “Kiss Me
column9: ” starring John Corbett
column10: Sarah Bolger
column11: Rita Wilson
column12: Emily Osment
column13: Missy Pyle and Jenna Fisher. Probst hosts the ""Howard Stern Celebrity Fan Roundtable"" for Howard Stern on Sirius/XM radio and previously served as host of VH1's ""Rock and Roll Jeopardy.” He hosted several programs for FX and traveled around the world as a correspondent for ""Access Hollywood."" In 2001
column14: he was voted one of People Magazine's ""Most Beautiful."" Probst is a proud spokesperson for Taylorsgift.org whose mission is to re-gift life through organ donation. Probst is also an ordained minister and has served as the officiant at the weddings of several friends. He was ordained by the Universal Life Church of Modesto
column15: California. A native of Wichita

column17: Probst lives with his family in Los Angeles when not traveling the world. His birthday is November 4. He can be followed on Twitter @jeffprobst.",32,0

Probst hosts the ""Howard Stern Celebrity Fan Roundtable"" for Howard Stern on Sirius/XM radio and previously served as host of VH1's ""Rock and Roll Jeopardy.” He hosted several programs for FX and traveled around the world as a correspondent for ""Access Hollywood."" column1: Jeff Probst,"Jeff Probst is a four-time Emmy Award winner for ""Outstanding Reality Host."" He has traveled the world serving as both host and executive producer forSurvivor. Also
column2: he received an Emmy in 2001 when the show won the first-ever ""Outstanding Non-Fiction Program (Special Class)."" Probst is a New York Times best-selling author of a kid’s adventure series
column3: Stranded. Probst is also a feature film director. In 2002
column4: he wrote and directedFinder's Fee
column5: starring Ryan Reynolds
column6: James Earl Jones
column7: Robert Forster and Matthew Lillard. Most recently
column8: he produced and directed the feature filmKiss Me
column9: starring John Corbett
column10: Sarah Bolger
column11: Rita Wilson
column12: Emily Osment
column13: Missy Pyle and Jenna Fischer. Probst hosts theHoward Stern Celebrity Fan Roundtablefor Howard Stern on Sirius/XM radio and previously served as host of VH1'sRock and Roll Jeopardy. He hosted several programs for FX and traveled around the world as a correspondent forAccess Hollywood. In 2001
column14: he was voted one of People Magazine's ""Most Beautiful."" Probst is a proud spokesperson for Taylorsgift.org whose mission is to re-gift life through organ donation. Probst is also an ordained minister and has served as the officiant at the weddings of several friends. He was ordained by the Universal Life Church of Modesto
column15: California. A native of Wichita

It's called ""He Didn't Have to Be."" It talks about how his stepfather was a great father to him and he hoped that he can be half the dad that he didn't have to be. That describes how I feel about Tim.If you could have three things on the island what would they be and why?A picture of my kids because I will miss them terribly. column1: Jeff Probst,"Jeff Probst is a four-time Emmy Award winner for Outstanding Reality Host. He has traveled the world serving as both host and executive producer forSurvivor. He received an Emmy in 2001 when the show won the first-ever Outstanding Non-Fiction Program (Special Class) award. column2: Heroes vs. Villains(winner)
column3: Game ChangersWhat specific accomplishments do you think ultimately earned you the moniker of ""Idol"" when it comes toSurvivor?This is probably the easiest question to answer. I am considered an Idol because I am the only castaway to ever win the game twice and to this day that has never happened again. I won the first season I ever appeared on back in 2003 and also won the second season I ever appeared on back in 2010. I'm not an Idol because I say I'm an Idol
column4: but because my record proves it. Nine years ago and 19 seasons ago I became known as the Queen
column5: and to this day no one has ever come close to tying my record.What do you think you can teach the new castaways to help them become Sole Survivor?I'm an open book when it comes to the seasons I've played in. I plan on sharing all aspects of the game with the castaways. I will be able to discuss situations like being flexible and how to go with the flow when you have no control over what the majority wants to do at a given time. How to build a strong alliance
column6: by trusting people you genuinely like and share common interests with. And that no one is perfect
column7: there's no way to play a perfect game
column8: so when you make a mistake
column9: own it.What part of the game do you think new castaways usually underestimate?The new castaways underestimate how hard the social part of the game truly is. Hard because there's people you will automatically like and people you will automatically dislike. With those you like
column10: you immediately build a bond and trust
column11: yet there can only be one winner. It's easy to vote off people you dislike
column12: but when all those people are gone
column13: now you have to start voting off the ones you consider friends. And these are the friends that you just blindsided and 100 percent of the time are upset that you voted them off and yet you still have to also convince them to give you the million dollar prize. It's really a juggling act.How will being a mentor present a different challenge for you than actually competing in the game?Being a mentor is actually easier than playing the game

column15: listen to them carefully

column16: a true survivor. Faced with unknown odds
column17: he risked everything to have a chance at living. At 16 years old
column18: my father and his two cousins ran from the mountains of Laos—through jungles laced with landmines and buzzing with bullets from communist Viet Cong and Pathet Lao followers—to refugee camps in Thailand in an attempt to escape ethnic genocide of the Hmong and Mien people who were abandoned after being recruited for guerilla warfare. After miraculously making it across the Mekong River and into the camps
column19: he was relocated to Montana with nothing more than the clothes on his back. Despite the struggles of being forced into a totally foreign country with no immediate family members
column20: he has never given up on living life to its fullest potential. I have had the privilege of growing up without the fears of being exposed to Agent Orange
column21: ethnic persecution
column22: and displacement because of his resilience
column23: his perseverance
column24: his defiance
column25: and his traumatic experiences.What's one thing we wouldn't know from seeing a photo of you?In 2015

column41: and an overall boss!What's your primary motivation for being onSurvivor?Honestly
column42: I am here to show minority young folk and people across the world that they matter
column43: that their stories and narratives are important
column44: and that they should never doubt their existence regardless of what others say.Survivorhas been an integral part of my life. It showed me that a kid from Merced could dream of traveling abroad
column46: and be more than another statistic. I hope that winning the title of ""Sole Survivor"" inspires other kids to challenge the oppressive systems and institutions that seek to keep them down!Why do you think you'll ""survive""Survivor?I have accumulated grit from the challenges that I've faced throughout my life and have always been able to gain the trust and confidence of others. I believe I can use my unassuming image and 209 vernacular to fool others into believing that I am not an immediate threat. However
column47: I'd say I'm pretty crafty and will be able to use my smarts to create plans and execute votes that will eliminate anyone I feel is a threat to my game (if you're not with me
column48: you're dead to me). I also understand how to deal with big egos and personal quirks and can use my social skills to build confidence among all characters. Lastly
column49: I've got quite a mouth and can smack the Jury with an award-winning final Tribal Council speech to guarantee my win.",39,0

In 2015Survivorcelebrated its 30th edition 15 years since the series premiered on May 31

column26: I never received a single vote against me. I was able to disguise my strategic ability and knowledge of the game under my country accent and chill demeanor. I was able to fly under the radar and build one-on-one relationships with nearly every single player in the game. This time
column27: if I don't receive a single vote the entire game
column28: I will take it as an insult! Everyone has seen how brilliantly I playSurvivor. These legends won't fall for alliance names and my Kentucky charm as easily as a cast of complete strangers did. I won't be able to hide behind bigger threats. So this time
column29: I'm going to be even more aggressive. In short
column30: I am going to have as much fun as possible in the beginning. This is my dream come true and I want to take it all in. Then
column31: I am going to TURN IT ON. No player will be safe from the Kentucky Nick sneaky ninja assassin blindside! This game is where legends are made!,40,0
